ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: We learned about choice under uncertainty and asymmetric information. The first half of the course focused on risk attitudes and theoretical models of individual's preferences. We then studied models of adverse selection, moral hazard, screening, and signaling,
A better understanding of lotteries, risk aversion, and decision making. Models were well explained and presented clearly.
Knowledge of risk aversion, adverse selection and imperfect information
Review of statistical/probability mathematics and in-depth covering of economic concepts with uncertainty in mind.

I learned about economic approaches towards incorporating risks in models, and then models of asymmetric information and moral hazard. It was mostly an interesting and specific extension of the models used in Intermediate Micro.
I got some insights behind insurance and capital markets, as well as performance evaluation among other things, or at least how these things are thought about in the literature or theoretical side.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Professor Reiche is amazing! She presented the topics in an organized and clear way, which made understanding the course concepts much easier. The smaller class size also allowed students to easily ask questions during lecture. In addition, problem sets were structured well to develop a better understanding of the material.

Weaknesses: We spent a lot of time reviewing basic probability concepts and setting up choice under risk and uncertainty. Focusing less on these topics in class and spending more time on applications or extensions of the models in the latter half of the course would have improved the course.

Good course structure and lecture

Problem sets often required outside work
The professor and TA are extremely supportive. Lecture can be fast paced at times, but theres a lot of time in between psets to clarify doubts.

No weaknesses. The course starts with a review of probability and this gives a good introduction to the math that will be used in the course. From there the course builds on itself and allows students the opportunity to understand complex concepts.
The class was really well taught Professor Reiche was great! I thought at some points the class was a bit too methodical, and I would have enjoyed more of an intellectual challenge.

The course is quite based in the existing literature. It would have been great every now and then to zoom out to think about whether the theory matches the reality. Additionally, the professor would go fast enough so that she said we didn't need to take notes because the slides would be online, but as the material built on itself, and assumptions made in past slides, it was often really convenient to have those slides out, or to have taken the notes to e able to follow along meaningfully.  I think this should be suggested to future students, especially if the professor insists on maintaining a certain speed (presumably to get through more material, which is great that she wants to teach us more), to have the online slides out, or to have downloaded them before the students come to the class (classroom in the basement of Watson did not always have the best WiFi). (The slides can also be used to go a little ahead, as well as review something that was not quite heard properly, among other possible use-cases.)

I also wonder if periodic low-stakes quizzes (NOT "pop") could help enforce learning of the material.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you're interested in the topic! The class is not too challenging, and Professor Reiche does a great job of balancing the theoretical foundations of economic models while tying them into real-world applications and current research.
ABSOLUTELY!! PROFESSOR SOENJE IS SO CARING AND THE TA (JUSTUS FTW) WAS JUST AS AMAZING!
Yes, good senior seminar for economics students.
Would definitely recommend this course! Its an interesting senior seminar, and I believe it incorporates things youve learned in past econ classes nicely.
Yes but only if they enjoy mathematical economics. This course isn't easy and the math can be confusing and difficult to figure out.
Yes! It is a reasonably lowkey but interesting senior seminar taught by a great professor.
If you're just looking for a literal presentation of the theory and math laid out in the course description, then yes!
